question: Question_04_(b)
statement:
Consider the function $f(x)=e^x$ for 0 $\leq$ x $\leq$ 1.

Find the volume $V_2$ of the bowl when rotating $f(x)$ around the
$y$-axis. (Note: for this problem there are two ways to set the relevant
integral up - either one is fine. One way involves rewriting $f(x)$ as
$x=g(y)$.)
sols:
\textbf{Disc Method.} In this solution, we consider the volume as a sum
of slices, cut orthogonal to the $y$-axis. Each slice has volume
$\pi r^2 \Delta y$, where $r$ is its radius and $\Delta y$ is its
thickness. The bowl will be made by rotating the shaded blue region in
the 2D figure \includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png}. If the
slice is at height $y$, then its radius is equal to $x$, where $y=e^x$.
Hence, $r=\ln y.$ In the limit $\Delta y\to 0,$

\begin{align*}
V_2= \int_1^e \pi (\ln y)^2 \, dy
\end{align*}

Note that the limits of integration are $f(0)=e^0=1$ and $f(1)=e^1=e,$
since $x$ ranges from 0 to 1.

We use integration by parts to evaluate this integral, letting
$f(y)=g(y)=\ln y.$ So in order to perform the integration by parts we
need to recall the antiderivative of $\ln y$. To calculate this
antiderivative we again use integration by parts:

\begin{align*}
\int \ln y dy &= \int 1\cdot \ln y\, dy = y\ln y - \int y \cdot \frac{1}{y} \, dy \\
&= y\ln y -  \int 1 \, dy= y\ln y -  y +C.
\end{align*}

We now use this antiderivative to perform the integration by parts in
the integral for $V_2.$ Hence,

\begin{align*}
V_2&=\pi \int_1^e  (\ln y)^2 \, dy \\
&= \pi \left[ \ln y (y\ln y -  y)\right]_1^e - \pi\int _1^e \frac{1}{y}(y\ln y -  y) \, dy\\
&= \pi \left[ 1 (e\cdot 1 -  e) - 0\right] - \pi\int _1^e (\ln y -  1) \, dy\\
&= - \pi\left[y\ln y-y -  y\right]_1^e \\
&= - \pi\left[e\ln e-e-e - 1\ln 1+1+1\right] \\
&= - \pi\left( - e +2\right) \\
&= \pi\left(  e-2 \right). \\
\end{align*}

\emph{Reality check:} Note that we obtain the same value for $V_2$ with
both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png}.

\textbf{Shell method.} In this solution, we consider the solid to be a
sum of cylindrical shells. Each cylindrical shell has volume
$2\pi r(x) h(x) \Delta r,$ where $r(x)$ is its radius, $h(x)$ is its
height and $\Delta r$ is its thickness. The bowl will be made up by
rotating the blue shaded region in the 2D figure
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math103Apr11Q4b-2dgraph.png}. From there we have
$r(x)=x$, $h(x)=f(1)-f(x) = e-e^x,$ and $\Delta r =\Delta x$. In the
limit $\Delta x \to 0,$ we obtain the volume by integrating along the
\emph{x}-axis:

\begin{align*}
V_2 &= \int_0^1 2\pi r(x)h(x) \, dx \\
&= \int_0^1 2\pi x (e-e^x) \, dx\\
&= 2\pi e \int_0^1  x\, dx -2\pi \int_0^1 x e^x \, dx\\
&= 2\pi  e \left[\frac{x^2}{2}\right]_0^1 -2\pi \left(\left[x e^x\right]_0^1-\int_0^1 e^x \, dx\right)\\
&= 2\pi  e \frac{1}{2} -2\pi \left( e- \left[e^x\right]_0^1 \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \left( e- (e-1) \right)\\
&= \pi  e  -2\pi \\
&= \pi  (e  -2).
\end{align*}

(We used integration by parts in the second integral to get from the
third to the fourth line.)

\emph{Reality check:} Note that we obtain the same value for $V_2$ with
both methods. To visualize the full bowl we can look at the 3D figure
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math103Apr11Q4b-3dgraph.png}.
hints:
Draw a picture. Visualize the two ways of integrating as referred to in
the hint.

Write down two integrals that represent the volume $V_2$ of the solid.
Which one would you prefer to evaluate?

In this case, both integrals are possible to evaluate using the
techniques that you've learned. It is a good reality check (and also a
good exercise) to compute both integrals and ensure that you obtain the
same result.
